abstracts.cdata!:
This is the Implementation Completion
            Report (ICR) for the Malawi Entrepreneurship Development and
            Drought Recovery Program (EDDRP). The objectives of the
            EDDRP were to broaden economic participation, to enable a
            sustainable supply response, and to prevent widespread
            starvation as a result of severe drought through a set of
            mutually reinforcing policy measures in the following areas:
            (i) improvement of the environment for entrepreneurial
            activity and investment in labor-intensive activities; (ii)
            expansion of access to financial capital and deepening of
            financial markets; (iii) reorientation of fiscal and labor
            policy towards human capital development; and (iv)
            procurement of commercial maize imports. Bank's
            performance was satisfactory. Borrower's performance
            was satisfactory. The key lessons learned were as follows:
            (i) with strong government commitment a country can stay on
            the adjustment course despite large unanticipated external
            shocks; (ii) adjustment in countries with extremely low
            income levels like Malawi, is a long-term process and will
            continue into the next decade; (iii) cross-conditionality
            with other International Development Association (IDA)
            projects resulted in "marginalizing" some
            objectives and created supervision problems; (iv)
            flexibility in the design and implementation of the program
            to respond to new information or emerging problems during
            implementation is criticalfor success; (v) irreversible
            up-front actions enhance prospects for successful
            implementation; and (vi) timely Balance of Payments (BOP)
            support to address natural disasters can be extremely
            important for keeping the overall adjustment program on track.
